qas.question: What location means that Antarctica get little solar radiation?
In what condition is most water in the Antarctica?
What is the usual condition of precipitation in the Antarctic?
What does the massed snow in Antarctica produce?
What are ice streams otherwise called?

plausible_answers.text: Due to its location at the South Pole

qas.question: Why does Antarctica receive solar radiation?
What continent is a complete desert?
What is next to the continental shelves?
What are temperatures like offshore to effect global cooling?

context: <b5_0>Due to its location at the <a0_0>South Pole<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Antarctica receives relatively little solar radiation. This means that it is a very cold continent where water is mostly in the form of <a1_0>ice<a1_0/>. Precipitation is low (most of <b6_0>Antarctica<b6_0/> is a desert) and almost always in the form of <a2_0>snow<a2_0/>, which accumulates and forms a <a3_0>giant ice sheet<a3_0/> which covers the land. Parts of this ice sheet form moving <a4_0>glaciers<a4_0/> known as ice streams, which flow towards the edges of the continent. Next to the continental shore are many <b7_0>ice shelves.<b7_0/> These are floating extensions of outflowing glaciers from the continental ice mass. Offshore, temperatures are also <b8_0>low<b8_0/> enough that ice is formed from seawater through most of the year. It is important to understand the various types of Antarctic ice to understand possible effects on sea levels and the implications of global cooling.
